title: Question 59

children: A 55-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure following a 2-day history of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. She required prolonged hospitalization in the ICU 10 months ago following a motor vehicle accident. During that time, she was treated with ciprofloxacin for
Pseudomonas
hospital-acquired pneumonia. She takes no medications.

On physical examination, the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Temperature is 39.2 °C (102.6 °F), blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg, pulse rate is 120/min, and respiration rate is 18/min. Oxygen saturation is 94% with a positive end-expiratory pressure of 10 cm H
O, and an F
IO
of 0.5. Crackles are heard at the lung bases bilaterally.
Gram stain of endotracheal tube aspirate shows moderate leukocytes, moderate gram-negative rods, and some yeast. COVID-19 testing is negative.
Chest radiograph shows bilateral opacities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial treatment?
Empiric therapy for
Pseudomonas
community-acquired pneumonia is recommended in two situations: growth from a respiratory tract culture in the previous year, or hospitalization and parenteral antibiotics in the preceding 3 months.
The most appropriate initial treatment for this patient is cefepime and levofloxacin (
Option A
). She has severe community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) that requires an antibiotic regimen with coverage for
Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Guidelines recognize two scenarios when empiric therapy for
Pseudomonas

is indicated: (1) growth from a respiratory tract culture in the previous year, or (2) hospitalization and parenteral antibiotics in the preceding 3 months (which is also a risk factor for methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus
[MRSA] CAP).
Pseudomonas
accounts for less than 5% of all CAP infections; however, previous isolation of the organism from sputum is associated with a 16-fold increased risk of subsequent infection. Other risk factors for
Pseudomonas
CAP include previous tracheostomy, bronchiectasis, and severe COPD. In patients who have been hospitalized in the preceding 3 months and received parenteral antibiotics, empiric therapy for both
Pseudomonas
and MRSA is recommended for severe (e.g., requiring ICU care) CAP. Antibiotic de-escalation can be pursued if cultures are negative at 48 hours.

Vancomycin is unnecessary in this patient who does not have risk factors for MRSA pneumonia (e.g., previous MRSA growth in a respiratory specimen, recent hospitalization with parenteral antibiotics, injection drug use), so the combination of cefepime, vancomycin, and levofloxacin is not indicated (
Option B
No antifungal therapy is necessary in this patient despite the Gram stain findings, so the regimen containing micafungin would be unnecessary (
Option C
). The presence of yeast in a respiratory specimen is rarely clinically significant but rather represents oropharyngeal colonization with
Candida
species. Furthermore, the acute onset of symptoms in this patient argues against a fungal cause.
Ceftaroline (combined with a second agent such as azithromycin) could be a CAP therapy option for a patient who does not have risk factors for
Pseudomonas
Option D
). However, this antibiotic lacks antipseudomonal activity, so it would not be an appropriate choice for this patient.

objective.__html: Treat severe community-acquired pneumonia in a patient with risk factors for Pseudomonas infection.

references: Restrepo MI, Babu BL, Reyes LF, et al; GLIMP. Burden and risk factors for Pseudomonas aeruginosa community-acquired pneumonia: a multinational point prevalence study of hospitalised patients. Eur Respir J. 2018;52.
